content: The "Border Patrol Pay Reform Act of 2013" may be cited as the short title. The Act addresses the Border Patrol rate of pay. The "Border Patrol Pay Reform Act of 2013" aims to strengthen U.S. Customs and Border Protection by ensuring Border Patrol agents are ready for necessary work and can perform overtime hours as needed. It also provides flexibility for shift changes and work assignments based on operational requirements. The "Border Patrol Pay Reform Act of 2013" enhances U.S. Customs and Border Protection by defining the rates of pay for Border Patrol agents based on their availability for unscheduled duty. The "Border Patrol Pay Reform Act of 2013" defines rates of pay for Border Patrol agents based on their availability for unscheduled duty, including covered border patrol activities such as detecting and preventing illegal entry and smuggling into the United States. The "Border Patrol Pay Reform Act of 2013" outlines various scenarios where Border Patrol agents may be excused from duty, including attending training, approved leave, travel status, official time, excused absence for relocation, light duty due to injury or disability. The "Border Patrol Pay Reform Act of 2013" allows Border Patrol agents to be excused from duty for various reasons, including injury, disability, administrative duties, caring for assigned canines, or similar activities while away from their regular assignment. The "Border Patrol Pay Reform Act of 2013" defines the level 1 and level 2 border patrol rates of pay for Border Patrol agents, as well as the work period as a 14-day biweekly pay period. Agents can voluntarily elect to receive the Border Patrol rate of pay. The Border Patrol Pay Reform Act of 2013 requires Border Patrol agents to choose between level 1, level 2, or decline both border patrol rates of pay annually. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management will establish procedures for Border Patrol agents to make an election between different pay rates. U.S. Customs and Border Protection will provide information on available elections to agents 60 days before each year. Border Patrol agents failing to elect timely will be deemed to have made an election. Congress suggests that U.S. Customs and Border Protection ensure that no more than 10% of agents decline the level 1 or level 2 border patrol pay rates. The text discusses the level 1 border patrol rate of pay for Border Patrol agents who elect it, outlining their work schedule and overtime hours. The Border Patrol agent shall receive pay at the level 1 border patrol rate of pay for regular work hours and shall not receive additional compensation or compensatory time off for scheduled overtime work. Any hours available for work during a work period will be included in regular time or overtime hours. The Border Patrol agent shall receive compensatory time off or pay at the overtime hourly rate for hours worked in excess of 100 hours during a work period, and shall be charged leave in increments of 8 hours for 1 shift of leave. The Border Patrol agent with an election under paragraph (1)(A)(ii) works 5 days a week, with 8 hours of regular time and 1 additional hour of scheduled overtime each day. The Border Patrol agent receives pay at the level 2 border patrol rate for scheduled overtime work, without additional compensation or compensatory time off. Any available work hours during a work period are included in regular time. The Border Patrol agent receives compensatory time off or pay at the overtime hourly rate for hours worked in excess of 90 hours during a work period. Leave is charged in increments of 8 hours for 1 shift, regardless of its length. The Border Patrol agent with an election under paragraph (1)(A)(iii) works 8 hours per day, 5 days a week, with any available work hours included. They receive compensatory time off or pay for overtime hours worked. The Border Patrol agent is eligible for compensatory time off or pay for overtime hours worked, as well as premium pay for night work, Sunday, and holiday pay. Border Patrol agents can waive the limitation on overtime hours with prior approval, but must use any compensatory time off within a year.
